msContents.summary: The Pañcarakṣā corpus ("Five Protections") consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī. The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. This Bengalese manuscript, dated to the second half of the 11th century and commissioned by the queen Ḍaddākā (probably the same as the Lāḍākā mentioned in Add.1464), is one of the oldest known examples of such a collection and is decorated with a series of thirty-six refined miniatures.

msItem.title: Pañcarakṣā
msItem.incipit:
[1v1] evam mayā śru%tam ekasmin samaye bhagavān mahāvajrame:[miniature]ruśikharakūṭāgāre viharati sma || mah a ā
%vajrasamādhibhūmipratiṣṭhāne | mah a ā
[miniature]vajra1 lpavṛkṣasamalaṅkṛte |
msItem.explicit: [70r3] yānī[miniature]ha bhūtāni samāgatāni sthitāni bhūmāv a%thavāntarīkṣe | kurvantu maitrīṃ satatam pra[miniature]jāsu divā ca rātrau ca carantu dharmam_ || [70r4] -3-a buddhānām buddhānubhāvena de:[miniature]vatānān devatānubhāvena mahāītir upaśānteti || @ ||
msItem.colophon: [70r4] ye dha:[miniature]rmā hetuprabhavā hetus teṣān tathāgatao [70r5] -4- | teṣāñ ca yo nirodha eva:[miniature]mvādī mahāśramaṇaḥ || deyadharmo: % yam pravarama:::@::hāyānayā[miniature]yinyāḥ paramopasikārājñī ḍaddākā%yā yad atra puṇya:::@::n tad bha:[miniature]vatv ācāryopādhyāyamātāpitṛ:[70r6] -4-ṅ kṛtvā sakalasatvarāśer a[miniature]nuttarajñānāvāptaya iti || @ || % paramasaugatamahārājadhirājapara[miniature]meśvaraśrīman nayapāladevapravarddhamānavi%jayarājye saṃvat_ 14 caitradine 17 [miniature]likhiteyam bhaṭṭārikā iti ||

supportDesc.foliation: Pāla numerals, beneath the right string hole, verso.
supportDesc.condition: Incomplete, generally in good condition; some modern restorations in the margins. The manuscript is worm-eaten at places and the writing is occasionally faded. The margins of the last folio are very worn out.

layout.p: 5-6 lines per page, approximately 122 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: Two string holes. The string holes are approximately in the middle of 2 to 2.50 cm-wide blank spaces framed by double parallel lines in black ink running through the whole height of the leaf. These are identical to those found in the outer margins of the written area, which is thus divided into three sections.
layout.p: Marginal frame lines in black ink, A pair of two parallel lines divided by a wider space; ruling.
The puṣpikās are always finely drawn in black ink in a decorative shape.

decoNote.desc:
Some leaves are decorated with three polichrome miniatures, varying in width between approx. 4.5 and 6 cm, framed by double parallel lines. The central miniature is slightly larger than the lateral ones. On such leaves the written area is thus divided into five sections.
There are 36 miniatures in an elaborate iconographic scheme that is at present somewhat obscure. Pañcarakṣā Mss. are usually illustrated by paintings of the five goddesses, with or without their equivalent Jinas. Here this pattern is not adhered to (Losty 1982: 31).
On f. 1v and f. 2r, representations of the goddess Pratisarā and five of the Mortal Buddhas.
On f. 19v and f. 20r, representations of the goddess Māyūrī, the two remaining Mortal Buddhas, Maitreya, Vajrapāṇi and Tārā.
On f. 45v and f. 46r, representations of the goddess Sāhasrapramardanī, four Bodhisattvas and a stūpa being worshipped by two figures.
On f. 64v and f. 65r, representations of the goddess Śītavatī, Mañjuśrī, Padmapāṇi and three goddesses.
On f. 66v and f. 67r, representations of the goddess Mantrānusāraṇī and five terrifying figures of yoginīs.
On 69v and f. 70r, representations of the same five yoginīs around Maitreya.
On the outer side of the back cover, traces of materials smeared on the manuscript during worship rites.

origin.origDate: 14th regnal year of Nayapāla of Bengal / 1054 CE according to Bendall (1883: 175) or 1057 CE according to Losty (1982: 31).

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright in 1873-6.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
